attacks.description: Execute a simple PowerShell command to get the current date.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current date and time.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to compress a file in the temp directory, demonstrating file operation capabilities.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named test.zip will be created in the temp directory containing the test.txt file.

attacks.description: Execute a PowerShell command that produces a beep sound, demonstrating interaction with system components.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will produce a beep sound.

attacks.description: List files in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the temporary directory

attacks.description: Create a file in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temporary directory

attacks.description: Execute a script that prints the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the current date

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command that outputs a test string to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Test PowerShell execution' is printed to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command that creates a temporary text file with sample data and then reads it back.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is created in the user's TEMP directory containing 'Sample data', and its contents are displayed.

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command that uses a built‑in binary (certutil) to decode a Base64 string into a readable file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Base64 string 'SGVsbG8gV29ybGQh' (which decodes to 'Hello World!') is written to a temporary file, decoded by certutil into msg.txt, and the decoded text is displayed.

attacks.description: Basic command to get a list of running processes using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes without requiring elevated privileges.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that creates a file using PowerShell on Linux, demonstrating file operations with -Force.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named testfile.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World', overwriting any existing file due to -Force.

attacks.description: Advanced command that downloads a webpage using PowerShell on Linux, handling potential errors silently.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the content of http://example.com to /tmp/example.html, ignoring any errors that might occur during the download process.

attacks.command: sc.exe \\TARGET_HOST create TestService binPath= "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\\remote.txt" && sc.exe \\TARGET_HOST start TestService
attacks.description: Creates a temporary service on the remote host that runs cmd.exe to write a test string to a temp file, then starts the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named TestService appears on TARGET_HOST, starts, and a file named remote.txt containing the word 'test' is created in the remote system's %TEMP% directory.

attacks.command: wmic /node:"TARGET_HOST" /user:"ADMIN_USER" /password:"PASSWORD" process call create "cmd.exe /c echo intermediate > %TEMP%\\intermediate.txt"
attacks.description: Uses WMIC to remotely create a process on the target that writes a test string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote host executes the cmd.exe command, resulting in a file named intermediate.txt in %TEMP% containing the word 'intermediate'.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-Command -ComputerName TARGET_HOST -ScriptBlock { $action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'cmd.exe' -Argument '/c echo advanced > $env:TEMP\\advanced.txt'; $trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -AtLogOn; Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'AdvTask' -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -Force }"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell Remoting to register a scheduled task on the remote machine that writes a test string to a temp file at the next logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named AdvTask is created on TARGET_HOST. When the next user logs on, the task runs cmd.exe, creating advanced.txt in the user's %TEMP% directory containing the word 'advanced'.

attacks.description: Basic remote command execution using SSH
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files on the remote host

attacks.description: Intermediate command execution creating a directory and file on the remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory and a file with specified content on the remote host

attacks.description: Advanced command execution requiring admin privileges to write to a root-owned file
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes to a file in the root directory, requiring sudo privileges

attacks.description: Collect basic system information (OS version, hostname, uptime, etc.) and store it in a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\systeminfo.txt containing the output of systeminfo.exe.

attacks.description: Enumerate autorun registry keys under HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run and save the list to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\run_keys.txt with the registry entries that define programs set to run at startup.

attacks.description: Read the local hosts file and write its contents to a temporary file for exfiltration or analysis.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\hosts.txt containing the text of the system's hosts file.

attacks.description: Gathers system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information such as the kernel version, hostname, and operating system name.

attacks.description: Views user accounts on the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts on the system, excluding passwords which are stored in /etc/shadow.

attacks.description: Searches for configuration files across the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists paths to configuration files found on the system, potentially revealing sensitive information or system settings.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "reg save HKLM\SYSTEM %TEMP%\system.hive /y && reg save HKLM\SAM %TEMP%\sam.hive /y"
attacks.description: Exports the SYSTEM and SAM registry hives to temporary files using reg.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files (system.hive and sam.hive) are created in the %TEMP% directory containing the raw registry hives.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "vssadmin create shadow /for=C: > %TEMP%\shadow.txt && for /f \"tokens=3\" %i in ('type %TEMP%\shadow.txt ^| find \"Shadow Copy Volume\"') do set SHADOW=%i && copy \"%SHADOW%\\Windows\\System32\\config\\SAM\" %TEMP%\\sam_shadow.hive /y && copy \"%SHADOW%\\Windows\\System32\\config\\SYSTEM\" %TEMP%\\system_shadow.hive /y"
attacks.description: Creates a volume shadow copy of C:, extracts the shadow path, and copies the SAM and SYSTEM hives from the shadow volume to %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files (sam_shadow.hive and system_shadow.hive) appear in %TEMP% containing the hives taken from the shadow copy.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "schtasks /Create /SC ONCE /ST 00:00 /RL HIGHEST /TN DumpCreds /TR \"cmd.exe /c \"reg save HKLM\\SYSTEM %TEMP%\\system_task.hive /y && reg save HKLM\\SAM %TEMP%\\sam_task.hive /y\"\" && schtasks /Run /TN DumpCreds && schtasks /Delete /TN DumpCreds /F"
attacks.description: Creates a one‑time scheduled task that runs reg saves under the SYSTEM account, executes it, then removes the task.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task runs, producing system_task.hive and sam_task.hive in %TEMP%, then the task is deleted.

attacks.description: View user accounts
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts on the system

attacks.description: Combine passwd and shadow files for cracking
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named credentials.txt containing combined user and password information

attacks.description: View shadow file using sudo
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the contents of the shadow file, including encrypted passwords

attacks.description: Lists all installed quick fix engineering (QFE) updates on the system, demonstrating basic system discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of installed updates.

attacks.description: Lists all running processes on the system in brief format, showing an intermediate use of WMI for system discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a concise list of running processes.

attacks.command: wmic /node:localhost process call create "cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test.txt"
attacks.description: Creates a new process on the local machine using WMI, executing a command that writes a test string to a file in the temp directory, demonstrating an advanced use of WMI for command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new file named test.txt in the temp directory containing the string 'Test'.

attacks.description: Discover block devices and their properties
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists block devices, their file systems, sizes, mount points, and labels

attacks.description: Discover CPU architecture and information in JSON format
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays CPU information in JSON format, including architecture, cores, and threads

attacks.description: Execute a simple command using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the command and prints 'Hello, World!' to the console

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Start-Process 'cmd.exe' -ArgumentList '/c echo This is a test > %TEMP%\test.txt'"
attacks.description: Tricks the user into executing a command that creates a test file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file in the temp directory

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo This is a test > %TEMP%\test.txt && start %TEMP%\test.txt"
attacks.description: Tricks the user into executing a command that creates a test file in the temp directory and opens it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file in the temp directory and opens it

attacks.description: Tricks the user into executing a command that compresses a test file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses a test file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Basic command to create a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file in the user's home directory

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "This is a test command" > /tmp/test.txt'
attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a test file in a system directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file in the /tmp directory, requiring admin privileges

attacks.description: Advanced command to download and execute a script from a URL
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script from a URL and executes it, potentially allowing for malicious activity

attacks.description: Displays detailed information about the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt window

attacks.description: Retrieves comprehensive network configuration details
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed network configuration information

attacks.description: Fetches information about the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays information about the current user

attacks.description: Gather basic system information using 'uname' command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output basic system information, including the kernel name, hostname, and kernel version.

attacks.description: Collect detailed system information using 'cat /etc/os-release' command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output detailed system information, including the operating system name, version, and ID.

attacks.description: Gather information about the Linux distribution using 'lsb_release' command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output information about the Linux distribution, including the distributor, release, and codename.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c echo 'Test Service' > %TEMP%\test.txt"
attacks.description: Create a new service named TestService that executes a command to write to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service is created, and a file named test.txt is written to the temp directory containing the text 'Test Service'.

attacks.description: Start the TestService service, executing the command specified during its creation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service starts, and the command it is configured to run is executed, resulting in the creation or modification of the test.txt file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: net.exe stop TestService && net.exe start TestService
attacks.description: Stop and then start the TestService service, demonstrating control over the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service is stopped and then started again, with the associated command being executed upon start, potentially updating the test.txt file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Start a test service named mytestservice
attacks.expected_behavior: The test service mytestservice will be started, demonstrating service execution for persistence.

attacks.description: Enable a test service named mytestservice to start at boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The test service mytestservice will be enabled to start at boot, demonstrating persistence.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "[Service]" > /etc/systemd/system/mytestservice.service; echo "ExecStart=/bin/echo Test Service Executed" >> /etc/systemd/system/mytestservice.service; systemctl daemon-reload; systemctl start mytestservice'
attacks.description: Create and start a test service that executes a simple command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service file will be created, and the service will be started, executing the command /bin/echo Test Service Executed, demonstrating service execution for persistence.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using netcat to send the /etc/passwd file to a C2 server at 192.168.1.100:4444
attacks.expected_behavior: The /etc/passwd file is sent to the C2 server, demonstrating basic data exfiltration

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration by archiving /etc/ directory and sending it via netcat to a C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: An archive of the /etc/ directory is created and sent to the C2 server, demonstrating more complex data exfiltration

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using reverse SSH tunnel to exfiltrate /etc/passwd
attacks.expected_behavior: A reverse SSH tunnel is established, and the /etc/passwd file is exfiltrated through it, demonstrating advanced data exfiltration techniques

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be encoded and saved as encoded.txt in the temp directory

attacks.description: Decode a Base64 encoded string using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded string will be printed to the console

attacks.description: Create a file, obfuscate its contents using certutil, and then encode the file
attacks.expected_behavior: The file obfuscated.txt will be created, obfuscated, and then encoded, and the encoded file will be saved as obfuscated_encoded.txt in the temp directory

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation by renaming a malicious file to appear legitimate.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be renamed and moved to the Documents directory, potentially evading detection by appearing as a legitimate file.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using archiving to compress and hide a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be compressed into an archive, which is then moved to the Documents directory, making it less suspicious.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using base64 encoding to hide the contents of a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of the malicious file will be encoded in base64, saved to a new file, and then moved to the Documents directory, effectively hiding its malicious content from casual inspection.

attacks.command: echo '@reboot sleep 30 && sh -c "echo \"Hello from persistence\" > /tmp/persistence.log"' | crontab -
attacks.description: Adds a cron job for the current user that executes a command at reboot to simulate persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a user-level cron job that runs once at boot, waits 30 seconds, then writes a test message to /tmp/persistence.log. No elevated privileges required. Safe for testing in isolated environments.

attacks.command: sudo cp /lib/systemd/system/timers.target /etc/systemd/system/persistence.service && sudo sed -i 's/Description=.*$/Description=Persistence Service/' /etc/systemd/system/persistence.service && sudo sed -i 's/After=.*$/After=network.target\nExecStart=\/bin\/sh -c \"echo \\\"Network persistence triggered\\\" >> \/tmp\/system-persistence.log\"/' /etc/systemd/system/persistence.service && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable persistence.service && sudo systemctl start persistence.service
attacks.description: Creates a system-wide systemd service by copying and modifying an existing service file to establish persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies a benign system unit file to /etc/systemd/system, modifies its description and ExecStart to log a message, then enables and starts it. Requires sudo. Simulates real-world attacker behavior of hijacking or cloning system services. Logs to /tmp/system-persistence.log. Safe as long as original system files are not corrupted.

attacks.description: Basic: Attempt to load a malicious DLL (test.dll) into the Windows Registry using regsvr32, which is a legitimate utility that can be used for DLL side-loading.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to unregister and load the test.dll, which should trigger detection mechanisms looking for DLL side-loading activity.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Use PowerShell to load the malicious DLL into the .NET runtime, leveraging the System.Windows.Forms assembly to execute the DLL.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command loads the test.dll into the .NET runtime, which can be detected by monitoring .NET assembly loads or process creation.

attacks.description: Advanced: Utilize rundll32.exe to load and execute the malicious DLL, specifying an entry point for execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command loads and executes the test.dll using rundll32, which is a common vector for DLL side-loading and should be detectable by monitoring process execution and DLL loads.

attacks.description: Attempts to preload a malicious library before executing a program, demonstrating a form of side-loading.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious library should be loaded instead of the legitimate one if the system is vulnerable.

attacks.description: Modifies the library path to include a directory with a malicious library, which could be loaded by a vulnerable application.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the application is vulnerable, it might load the malicious library instead of the intended one.

attacks.description: Compiles a malicious library and then attempts to preload it before executing a program, demonstrating a more advanced form of side-loading.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious library should be compiled and then loaded, potentially allowing for malicious activity if the system is vulnerable.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using certutil for encoding and PowerShell for the HTTP request
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a request using certutil and then sends it via an HTTP GET request

attacks.description: Advanced example directly using .NET classes for HTTP communication (violates the no .NET reflection rule, thus not recommended but shown for educational purposes)

attacks.description: Basic example using PowerShell to download and execute Mimikatz for credential dumping. This command assumes internet access for simplicity but is not recommended due to the potential for malicious payload download.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads Mimikatz and attempts to dump credentials. Note: This command is for demonstration and should not be used due to safety concerns.

attacks.description: Intermediate example assuming Mimikatz is already downloaded and located at a specific path. This approach is safer as it does not involve downloading potentially malicious content.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes Mimikatz from a local path to dump credentials.

attacks.description: Advanced example that checks if Mimikatz is located in the temp directory and executes it if found. This command demonstrates a more controlled approach to executing Mimikatz.
attacks.expected_behavior: Checks for Mimikatz in the temp directory and executes it to dump credentials if it exists.

attacks.description: Dump the shadow file to screen, which contains hashed passwords
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the contents of the shadow file, including hashed passwords

attacks.description: Search for the string 'password' in configuration files under /etc/, which could indicate where passwords are stored
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files under /etc/ that contain the string 'password'

attacks.description: Combine passwd and shadow files into a single file for analysis, simulating credential dumping
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named passwords.txt containing combined user and password information

attacks.description: Basic remote execution using SSH to run a simple command on the target host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command connects to the remote host and prints the username under which the SSH session runs.

attacks.description: Intermediate scenario: copies a benign script to the remote host and executes it via SSH.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is transferred to /tmp on the target, made executable, and run, producing its output (e.g., printing a test message).

attacks.description: Advanced lateral movement: uses SSH with disabled host‑key checking and a forced pseudo‑tty to run a sudo command that writes to a privileged location on the remote host.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the remote user has sudo rights, the command creates /etc/testfile containing the string "Test" and then displays its contents.

attacks.description: Exploits a public-facing application by downloading and executing a malicious executable from a hypothetical URL using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file and executes it, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to download an exploit from a hypothetical URL and then executes it, demonstrating exploitation of a public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file and executes it, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Creates a harmless file in the temp directory and attempts to execute it, simulating the initial steps of exploiting a public-facing application without causing harm.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file and attempts to open it, demonstrating initial exploitation steps without malicious intent.

attacks.description: Simulate an exploit by sending a GET request to a potentially vulnerable web application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a GET request to the specified URL and display the response in the console

attacks.description: Simulate an exploit by executing a bash command to create a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named exploit.txt in the /tmp directory with the contents 'Simulated exploit'

attacks.description: Simulate an exploit by sending a POST request with a simulated payload
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a POST request to the specified URL with a JSON payload and display the response in the console

attacks.description: This command demonstrates archiving a collected data file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet. It compresses a test file located in the user's temp directory into a zip archive, also in the temp directory, using the -Force parameter to overwrite any existing archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of a specified file in the temp directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name.

attacks.description: This command uses the makecab utility to create a cabinet file archive of a test file in the temp directory. It changes the directory to the temp folder and then uses makecab to archive the file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cabinet file archive of a specified file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: This command loads the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly and uses the ZipFile class to create a zip archive from a directory containing collected data. It's a more advanced approach to archiving data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of all files in a specified directory, demonstrating a more complex data collection and archiving scenario.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of data using tar command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive.tar.gz containing the data from /path/to/data

attacks.description: Archiving sensitive data to a root directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named archive.tar.gz in the root directory containing sensitive data, requiring admin privileges

attacks.description: Advanced archiving using find and tar commands
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds all files in /path/to/data and archives them into archive.tar.gz

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Test Task" /tr "cmd /c echo Hello World > %TEMP%\test.txt" /sc daily
attacks.description: Create a new scheduled task that runs a benign command daily
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created and runs daily, writing "Hello World" to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Schedule a task to run at 2:30 PM using the at utility, assuming a test.cmd file exists in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A task is scheduled to run at 2:30 PM, executing the test.cmd file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a new scheduled task using PowerShell that runs a benign command daily
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created and runs daily, writing "Hello World" to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to schedule a new task
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened for editing, allowing the user to schedule a new task

attacks.description: Schedule a task to run at 2:00 PM
attacks.expected_behavior: The user will be prompted to enter the command to be executed at 2:00 PM

attacks.description: Schedule a task to run at 2:00 PM and output the result to /dev/null
attacks.expected_behavior: The task will be scheduled to run at 2:00 PM and the output will be redirected to /dev/null

attacks.description: Basic Input Capture using PowerShell to log keystrokes to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Logs keystrokes to a file named 'input.log' in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate Input Capture by logging network input using the 'net' command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Logs network input to a file named 'network_input.log' in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Advanced Input Capture using PowerShell with encoding to capture and log sensitive user input.
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures and logs processes to a file named 'processes.log' in the TEMP directory using an encoded command.

attacks.description: Test the second input device (e.g., a keyboard) to capture input events.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the events captured from the specified input device, demonstrating input capture capability.

attacks.description: Simulate pressing the 'a' key to demonstrate input simulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'a' key will be simulated as if pressed by the user, showing how input can be generated programmatically.

attacks.description: Simulate typing 'Hello World' to demonstrate more complex input simulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello World' will be typed out as if by a user, further demonstrating input capture and simulation capabilities.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Add a registry key to execute a command when a user logs in
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry key is added to execute a command when a user logs in, creating a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Add a registry key to execute a command when a user logs in using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry key is added to execute a command when a user logs in, creating a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Add a registry key to execute a command when a user logs in, listing the directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry key is added to execute a command when a user logs in, listing the directory and creating a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Modifies the cron.d directory to add a test string, simulating a persistence technique by scheduling a task.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new file in /etc/cron.d/ and sets its permissions, potentially leading to execution of the contained command at the specified cron interval.

attacks.description: Appends a command to the user's crontab that creates a file at /tmp/test_file on reboot, demonstrating persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Modifies the user's crontab to execute a command on reboot, creating a test file.

attacks.description: Appends a test string to /etc/rc.local, which is executed on system startup, demonstrating another form of persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a command to rc.local, which will be executed on the next system boot.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a benign phishing email attachment' > %TEMP%\benign_attachment.txt
attacks.description: Create a benign text file in the temp directory, simulating a phishing email attachment
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named 'benign_attachment.txt' will be created in the temp directory

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; [System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox]::Show('This is a benign phishing attempt')"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to display a pop-up message, mimicking a phishing attempt
attacks.expected_behavior: A pop-up message box will appear with the text 'This is a benign phishing attempt'

attacks.description: Use the legacy binary 'certutil' to decode a benign string, simulating decoding a phishing payload
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named 'benign_string_decoded.txt' will be created in the temp directory with the decoded string
